subject: Keyman 6.0 layout
msgSnippet: I re-wrote my old keyboard layout in some idle time between classes. I ve uploaded the source code in the Files  Keyman layouts folder. I only finished this
messageBody:
I re-wrote my old keyboard layout in some idle time between classes.
I've uploaded the source code in the Files > Keyman layouts folder. I
only finished this thing about an hour ago, so it probably has bugs
in it.

If you want to use this, please download the keyman developer and
compile it yourself. I've included a little icon that keyman will put
on your task bar when the script is activated.

This keyboard layout allows Quickscript Junior input for QS fonts
with a non-unicode layout (I refer to this as "Jerome", named after
the first QS font I laid my hands on).

Traditionally, the fonts dictated the keyboard layout, and in order
to type Quickscript (or Shavian) one had to memorise all the
character's corresponding characters on the keyboard.

This keyboard interprets combinations of letters and converts these
to the appropriate Quickscript characters. The transcription scheme
is NewRomaji. I can't find any sources online about NewRomaji, it's
from something I printed out years ago. I made a few minor changes to
the "official" NewRomaji scheme. It'll also automatically convert n
to N when followed by a g or k.

In the Files > Keyman layouts folder you should find a png file which
explains this transcription scheme. I made it by modifying one of the
MS Excel files available at omniglot.com

Of course this keyman source code file can easily be adapted for
Shavian or even Unicode QS/Shavian scripts. Feel free to do so.
Please share your source and not the compiled Keyman drivers. From
what I understand, uncompiled ones can also be fed to a certain linux
program.

It's been a while since I've played around with Quickscript, are
there any Unicode QS fonts out yet?

Ewout Stam
/EvQt stym
